meta.title: Dr. Sarah Mitchell | Psychology Professor
meta.description: Academic portfolio showcasing research in cognitive psychology, publications, and teaching excellence

about.bio: Dr. Sarah Mitchell is a distinguished Professor of Psychology at UC Berkeley, specializing in cognitive psychology and memory research. Her groundbreaking work on learning processes has influenced educational practices worldwide and earned recognition from the American Psychological Association.
academicFocus: Advancing understanding of human memory and cognitive processes
Mentoring the next generation of psychological researchers
Bridging the gap between laboratory research and real-world applications

degrees.honors: Summa Cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa

experience.title: Professor of Psychology
experience.description: Lead research in cognitive psychology and memory sciences. Direct the Memory and Learning Lab with 12 graduate students and 2 postdoctoral researchers. Secured over $2.5M in NSF and NIH funding for groundbreaking research on memory formation and educational applications.
achievements: Published 45+ peer-reviewed articles in top-tier psychology journals
Mentored 23 doctoral students to successful completion of their degrees
Received the UC Berkeley Distinguished Teaching Award (2022)
Established international collaborations with Oxford and Max Planck Institute

experience.title: Associate Professor of Psychology
experience.description: Conducted innovative research in memory and learning processes. Developed novel experimental paradigms that advanced understanding of how memories are formed and retrieved. Taught graduate and undergraduate courses in cognitive psychology and research methods.
achievements: Secured $850K NSF CAREER Award for memory research
Published seminal work on memory consolidation in Nature Neuroscience
Developed new statistical methods for analyzing memory data
Established the Cognitive Development Research Consortium

experience.title: Assistant Professor of Psychology
experience.description: Launched independent research program investigating the neural mechanisms of memory formation. Established collaborations with neuroscience and education departments. Developed innovative teaching methods for statistics and research design courses.
achievements: Received Early Career Award from American Psychological Association
Published 15 articles in high-impact journals including Science and PNAS
Developed open-source software for memory research
